content.question: Which of the following is the enharmonic equivalent of the pitch above?

choices.label: The figure presents a staff with a treble clef. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm in the measure is: one whole note. The pitch of the note is A sharp 5.

The figure presents a staff with a treble clef. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm in the measure is: one whole note. The pitch of the note is G flat 5.

The figure presents a staff with a treble clef. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm in the measure is: one whole note. The pitch of the note is A flat 5.

The figure presents a staff with a treble clef. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm in the measure is: one whole note. The pitch of the note is G sharp 5.

content.answer: The figure presents a staff with a treble clef. There is no key signature or time signature. There is only one measure. The rhythm in the measure is: one whole note. The pitch of the note is A flat 5.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Use symbols and terms to describe features of pitch in notated music, including pitch patterns and relationships, melodic features, chords, harmonic progressions, and cadences.
